text: The parties’ cross-motions for summary judgment came on for hearing on April 9,
label: BODY

text: 2008 before this court.  Plaintiffs, XXXXXXX and XXXXXXXX (collectively
label: BODY

text: “plaintiffs”)1, appeared through their counsel, Susan Foley.  Defendant San Mateo Union
label: BODY

text: High School District (“defendant” or “District”) appeared through its counsel, Kimberly A.
label: BODY

text: Smith.  Having read all the papers submitted and carefully considered the relevant legal
label: BODY

text: authority, the court hereby GRANTS defendant’s motion for summary judgment, and
label: BODY

text: DENIES plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment, for the reasons stated at the hearing, and
label: BODY

text: as follows.
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND
label: H2

text: This case arises under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (“IDEA”), which
label: BODY

text: requires school districts to provide qualifying disabled children with a “free appropriate
label: BODY

text: public education” (“FAPE”).  See 20 U.S.C. § 1412(1).
label: BODY

text: Background Facts
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 1 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff XXXXXXX, who is currently twenty years old, was first made eligible as
label: BODY

text: a student with a Specific Learning Disability and a Speech Language Impairment, on
label: BODY

text: November 26, 1990, during his 3rd grade year.  See Administrative Record (“AR”) at 240.
label: BODY

text: He remained eligible for special education under these two categories for the duration of
label: BODY

text: his school career, including the time periods that are relevant for purposes of this lawsuit,
label: BODY

text: namely 2003-2006.  During that relevant time period, plaintiff attended Hillsdale High
label: BODY

text: School as a freshman during the 2002-03 school year, and as a sophomore for part of the
label: BODY

text: 2003-04 school year.  AR at 242, 251.
label: BODY

text: During plaintiff’s 9th grade year at Hillsdale, in fall of 2002, defendant San Mateo
label: BODY

text: Union High School District conducted plaintiff’s triennial review.  The triennial review refers
label: BODY

text: to the process of assessing and determining a student’s eligibility and placement needs
label: BODY

text: once every three years.  AR 852.  As part of the 2002 triennial review, defendant conducted
label: BODY

text: several assessments of plaintiff.  These assessments included administration of the Wide
label: BODY

text: Range Achievement Test (WRAT”), a Bruckner diagnostic math test, and the Peabot
label: BODY

text: Individual Achievement Test (“PIAT”).  AR at 587-88.  On the WRAT, plaintiff demonstrated
label: BODY

text: weakness in math and spelling, and high level decoding skills.  Id. at 589.  On the
label: BODY

text: Bruckner, plaintiff scored very well in addition and subtraction, but was weak in
label: BODY

text: multiplication and division.  AR at 591.  Plaintiff performed above grade level on the PIAT.
label: BODY

text: Id.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff was also observed in the classroom by an educational assistant, in order to
label: BODY

text: assess how plaintiff interacted with others in the classroom environment.  The educational
label: BODY

text: assistant reported that plaintiff did not require assistance, was not easily distracted by
label: BODY

text: others, and did not distract others, although he at times appeared lethargic.  AR at 594-95.
label: BODY

text: Finally, a District psychologist reviewed plaintiff’s student records and spoke with
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s teachers.  AR at 852-53.  Based on this review, she determined that no further
label: BODY

text: psychological testing of plaintiff was needed.  Id.  She sent plaintiff’s mother, XXXXXXX
label: BODY

text: XXXXXX, a confirming letter.  Id.  Ms. XXXXXXX did not request further assessments.  Id.
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 2 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: Following the completion of these triennial assessments, plaintiff’s Individualized
label: BODY

text: Education Plan (“IEP”) team convened on October 4, 2002 for the triennial review.  AR
label: BODY

text: 1145-63.  Among others, plaintiff and his mother were present at the meeting, as well as
label: BODY

text: Ms. Pam Rianda, plaintiff’s special education teacher, and Ms. Lisa Fox, plaintiff’s speech
label: BODY

text: and language therapist.  AR 1148.  The IEP team noted plaintiff’s areas of strength and
label: BODY

text: weakness, with plaintiff’s written language and math skills included in the latter category.
label: BODY

text: AR 1145.  The team also noted that plaintiff was experiencing problems with punctuality
label: BODY

text: and attendance, and was demonstrating some “defiant behaviors” and a “level of anger that
label: BODY

text: contribute[d] to [plaintiff’s] not being successful in school.”  AR 1148, 1223-25.  The IEP
label: BODY

text: team recommended that plaintiff continue to be placed in a Special Day Class (“SDC”) for 3
label: BODY

text: to 4 periods a day, and in order to address plaintiff’s observed speech and language
label: BODY

text: problems, it recommended that plaintiff be given 3 periods per month of direct speech and
label: BODY

text: language therapy.  AR 1146-48.  The team also recommended that plaintiff participate in
label: BODY

text: Hillsdale’s anger management program.  Id.  Ms. XXXXXXXX received notice of the
label: BODY

text: Procedural Safeguards, indicated she understood her rights, and consented to the IEP.  AR
label: BODY

text: On November 12, 2002, plaintiff’s IEP team convened again, in order to draft a
label: BODY

text: Behavior Support Plan (“BSP”).  AR 1243-49.  Prior to the meeting, the defendant had
label: BODY

text: requested consent to conduct an environmental assessment, which examines a student’s
label: BODY

text: behavior, discipline and school functioning.  AR 601-02; 1242.  The purpose of the
label: BODY

text: environmental assessment was to determine if plaintiff needed more support or services,
label: BODY

text: and to determine if plaintiff needed a BSP.  AR 602-03.  It appears that the environmental
label: BODY

text: assessment never took place.  Nonetheless, based on plaintiff’s general behavior and
label: BODY

text: school performance, the IEP team developed a BSP on November 12.  AR 603-05, 1249.
label: BODY

text: The BSP noted that plaintiff was exhibiting “inappropriate classroom behavior” that was
label: BODY

text: impeding plaintiff’s learning, and that the behavior was being caused by “anger,”
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 3 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: “frustration,” and a failure of success.  AR 1249.  To that end, the BSP outlined certain
label: BODY

text: interventions that were to be undertaken by defendant in an effort to modify plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: behavior.  The interventions consisted of specific teaching strategies, positive
label: BODY

text: reinforcement, one-to-one assistance when necessary, a tutorial study period, anger
label: BODY

text: management counseling, and weekly progress reports.  AR 604-05; 1170; 1249.  The BSP
label: BODY

text: did not, however, address any truancy issues that plaintiff was having, which had been
label: BODY

text: remarked upon earlier by the School Safety Advocate.  AR 1240.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff and his mother participated in the November 2002 IEP meeting, received the
label: BODY

text: Notice of Procedural Safeguards, indicated she understood her rights, and consented to
label: BODY

text: the IEP.  AR 308; 1246.  Defendant then implemented the BSP.  AR 605.  While plaintiff
label: BODY

text: continued to receive disciplinary referrals and suspensions after the creation of the BSP,
label: BODY

text: they were less frequent than the disciplinary referrals that plaintiff received prior to the
label: BODY

text: implementation of the BSP.  AR 652; 977.
label: BODY

text: Several months later, on April 8, 2003, Ms. XXXXXXX wrote to Marvin Meyers, the
label: BODY

text: District’s Director of Special Education, and requested a change of placement for her son,
label: BODY

text: due to plaintiff’s continuing behavior problems and his inability to benefit in his current
label: BODY

text: placement.  AR 248-49; 1252.  In response, an IEP team meeting was thereafter held on
label: BODY

text: May 1, 2003.  AR 1257-66.  As the reports submitted in connection with the May 2003 IEP
label: BODY

text: stated, plaintiff was continuing to exhibit negative behaviors, including tardiness, defiance
label: BODY

text: of authority, and use of profanity, among other things.  AR 1265.  Plaintiff’s behavior was
label: BODY

text: described as “totally distracting to the class and instruction.”  Id.  Nonetheless, based on
label: BODY

text: the information discussed with plaintiff’s teachers at the IEP team meeting, plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: mother “rescinded her request for change in placement,” and the May 2003 IEP resulted in
label: BODY

text: no changes to the October 4, 2002 and November 12, 2002 IEPs that were already in
label: BODY

text: Shortly thereafter, on May 13, 2003, plaintiff was arrested for stealing beer from a
label: BODY

text: San Mateo supermarket during school hours.  AR 995; 1285.  Defendant District was not
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 4 of 24

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: notified of plaintiff’s arrest, however, or of any subsequent juvenile court proceedings.
label: BODY

text: On November 13, 2003, plaintiff’s IEP team once again convened, this time for
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s annual review.  AR 1268-81.  The IEP team noted that plaintiff’s “greatest
label: BODY

text: weakness [was] his truancy.”  AR 1274.  The team further noted that it was difficult to
label: BODY

text: gauge whether plaintiff’s current placement was effective, due to excessive absences on
label: BODY

text: his part.  AR 695; 974.  In the area of speech and language, plaintiff’s truancy prevented
label: BODY

text: the IEP team from formally assessing plaintiff.  However, the speech and language
label: BODY

text: pathologist, Ms. Fox, was also plaintiff’s treating therapist for the past two years, and
label: BODY

text: therefore was able to review records and reflect on her observations of plaintiff during
label: BODY

text: therapy sessions, in order to identify speech and language needs, and draft accurate
label: BODY

text: present levels of performance.  AR 695; 974; 1279.  Ms. Fox also recommended modifying
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s speech and language goals, and changing to consultation speech services,
label: BODY

text: because of plaintiff’s frequent truancy.  AR 690-91.  Specifically, Ms. Fox was concerned
label: BODY

text: about the effect of pulling plaintiff out of his academic classes for speech, given his truancy
label: BODY

text: and poor grades.  By switching to speech and language services on a consultation basis,
label: BODY

text: the idea was to afford plaintiff a chance to improve his attendance.  Id.
label: BODY

text: In the area of academics, the November 2003 IEP team – which included plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: general education and special education teachers – developed accurate present levels of
label: BODY

text: performance based on current observations of plaintiff in the classroom.  AR 616-22; 969;
label: BODY

text: 971.  The team noted that plaintiff’s strengths included reading comprehension, vocabulary,
label: BODY

text: and creative writing.  Weaknesses included attendance, expository writing, and
label: BODY

text: mathematics.  AR 743-45.  The IEP team recommended placement in SDC for three
label: BODY

text: periods per day.  AR 968.
label: BODY

text: The IEP team also found that the November 2002 BSP was no longer appropriate,
label: BODY

text: as plaintiff’s primary struggle was now with truancy.  Accordingly, the IEP team developed
label: BODY

text: a new BSP at the November 2003 meeting.  This revised BSP provided for daily planner
label: BODY

text: checks, one-one-one assistance during tutorial at least twice a week, weekly progress
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 5 of 24
label: BODY

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: reports, positive progress reports sent home, and counseling from the District probation
label: BODY

text: officer to discuss the legal ramifications of plaintiff’s truancy.  AR 748; 750; 975.  The
label: BODY

text: November 2003 BSP also required plaintiff’s special education teacher to personally call
label: BODY

text: plaintiff on his cell phone when he did not appear in class, or to call Ms. XXXXXXX.  AR
label: BODY

text: 751.  Plaintiff was not referred to the County Mental Health Department.  Ms. XXXXXXX
label: BODY

text: participated in the November 2003 IEP team meeting, received the notice of procedural
label: BODY

text: safeguards, and consented to the IEP.  AR 315-16.
label: BODY

text: In the first two months following implementation of the BSP, between November
label: BODY

text: 2003 and January 2004, plaintiff’s grades improved.  AR 752.  In December 2003 and
label: BODY

text: January through February 2004, however, plaintiff received suspensions for truancy from
label: BODY

text: school, and for disrupting activities and defying school policies.  AR 1237-38; 1250.
label: BODY

text: On March 4, 2004, plaintiff’s May 2003 arrest was adjudicated by the Alameda
label: BODY

text: County Juvenile Court.  The court adjudged plaintiff a ward of the court and ordered plaintiff
label: BODY

text: to serve 60 days in juvenile hall.  AR 1000.  However, as an alternative to this sentence,
label: BODY

text: the court approved plaintiff’s enrollment in a wilderness program called the Rocky Mountain
label: BODY

text: Academy, in Colorado – at his parent’s expense.  AR 998-99; 1287.  Ultimately, Ms.
label: BODY

text: XXXXXXX enrolled plaintiff in the Ascent program in Idaho, a six week wilderness
label: BODY

text: intervention program.  AR 281; 380; 2006.  Plaintiff began the program at some point
label: BODY

text: between March 18 and March 21, 2004.  AR 998; 1002.  On March 22, 2004, Ms.
label: BODY

text: XXXXXXX informed plaintiff’s special education teacher, Ms. Hahn, that plaintiff was
label: BODY

text: attending the Ascent program.  AR 837.  She made no request that the District fund the
label: BODY

text: program.  AR 325-26.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff attended Ascent from March 22, 2004 through May 5, 2004.  AR 998; 1411.
label: BODY

text: While there, he made progress with certain maladaptive behaviors.  AR 384-85.  Upon his
label: BODY

text: completion of the program at Ascent, it was recommended by Ascent staff that plaintiff
label: BODY

text: attend a residential CEDU High School in San Bernardino.  AR 998; 1301.  On May 6,
label: BODY

text: 2004, the Juvenile Court adopted this recommendation, and upon the court’s order, plaintiff
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 6 of 24

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: attended the CEDU High School until its closure in March 2005.  AR 997; 1006; 1333.
label: BODY

text: While at CEDU, plaintiff earned a 2.60 GPA.  AR 1335.  After the CEDU school’s closure,
label: BODY

text: plaintiff was sent home while an appropriate school placement could be located.  Plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: probation officer noted in her report that no public or private schools met plaintiff’s needs in
label: BODY

text: the surrounding area.  AR 1296.  Court records indicate that, after weighing the options,
label: BODY

text: plaintiff and his parents concluded that the Mt. Bachelor Academy in Oregon was the best
label: BODY

text: placement, and that the court allowed plaintiff to be placed there at the parents’ expense.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff enrolled at Mt. Bachelor on May 11, 2005, where he finally graduated with a
label: BODY

text: High School Diploma in June 2006.  AR 1401.  While at Mt. Bachelor, plaintiff earned As,
label: BODY

text: Bs, and Cs, although he also continued to demonstrate behaviors such as truancy, low
label: BODY

text: grades, refusal to participate in class, and alcohol and tobacco abuse.  AR 1110-11; 1113;
label: BODY

text: On July 20, 2006, Ms. XXXXXXX filed a request for due process, seeking
label: BODY

text: reimbursement for plaintiff’s private placements.
label: BODY

text: The ALJ Decision
label: BODY

text: The due process hearing occurred on December 18-20, 2006.  See AR 228; 2106.
label: BODY

text: The Administrative Law Judge (“ALJ”), Suzanne Brown, considered the following issues at
label: BODY

text: the hearing:
label: BODY

text: Did the District deny plaintiff a FAPE from July 19, 2003 through the 2005-06
label: BODY

text: school year by failing to: (a) assess plaintiff’s behavioral needs; (b) meet plaintiff’s unique
label: BODY

text: needs for behavioral and mental health services;
label: BODY

text: Did the District deny plaintiff a FAPE from November 12, 2003, through the
label: BODY

text: 2005-06 school year by failing to: (a) have a school psychologist attend the November 13,
label: BODY

text: 2003 IEP team meeting; (b) assess plaintiff in the areas of behavior, speech and language,
label: BODY

text: and academics; (c) provide adequate present levels of performance in the November 13,
label: BODY

text: 2003 IEP in the areas of behavior, speech and language, and academics, which denied
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 7 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: plaintiff educational opportunity and his parent an opportunity to participate in the decision-
label: BODY

text: making process; (d) include adequate goals in the November 13, 2003 IEP in the areas of
label: BODY

text: behavior, speech and language, academics, and mental health, which denied plaintiff
label: BODY

text: educational opportunity and his parent an opportunity to participate in the decision-making
label: BODY

text: process; and (e) meet plaintiff’s unique speech and language needs in the areas of
label: BODY

text: dysfluency, and expressive receptive and pragmatic language skills; and
label: BODY

text: If the District denied plaintiff a FAPE, is Ms. XXXXXXX entitled to
label: BODY

text: reimbursement for private school placements from March 2004 to June 2006, and related
label: BODY

text: transportation costs.
label: BODY

text: ALJ Brown issued a decision on February 8, 2007.  With respect to the first issue,
label: BODY

text: the ALJ concluded that plaintiff failed to demonstrate that the District denied him a FAPE
label: BODY

text: from July 19, 2003 through the 2005-06 school year.  AR 158.  Specifically, the ALJ found
label: BODY

text: that the District had not failed to assess plaintiff’s behavioral needs, and furthermore did not
label: BODY

text: fail to assess plaintiff’s unique behavioral and mental health needs.  Id.  Similarly, on the
label: BODY

text: second issue, the ALJ also found that plaintiff had failed to establish that the District denied
label: BODY

text: him a FAPE from November 12, 2003 through the 2005-06 school year, and made specific
label: BODY

text: findings with respect to each of the sub-issues presented.  AR 158-59.  Finally, the ALJ
label: BODY

text: found that, with respect to the last issue, plaintiff’s mother is not entitled to reimbursement
label: BODY

text: for the private school placements or related transportation costs.  AR 159.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff now seeks reversal of the ALJ’s decision, reimbursement for educational
label: BODY

text: expenses, and attorneys’ fees and costs.  Defendant, by contrast, seeks an order affirming
label: BODY

text: the findings of the ALJ in their entirety.
label: BODY

text: DISCUSSION
label: H2

text: Legal Standards
label: BODY

text: Summary Judgment
label: BODY

text: Summary judgment shall be granted if “the pleadings, depositions, answers to
label: BODY

text: interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 8 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment
label: BODY

text: as a matter of law.”  FRCP 56(c).  Material facts are those which may affect the outcome of
label: BODY

text: the case.  See Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A dispute as to
label: BODY

text: a material fact is genuine if there is sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to return a
label: BODY

text: verdict for the nonmoving party.  Id.  The court must view the facts in the light most
label: BODY

text: favorable to the non-moving party and give it the benefit of all reasonable inferences to be
label: BODY

text: drawn from those facts.  Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574,
label: BODY

text: IDEA Claims
label: BODY

text: The IDEA requires school districts to provide disabled children with a “free
label: BODY

text: appropriate public education” (“FAPE”).  20 U.S.C. § 1412(1).  The education to which
label: BODY

text: access is provided must be “reasonably calculated to enable the child to receive
label: BODY

text: educational benefits.”  Bd. of Educ. of Hendrick Hudson Central Sch. Dist. Westchester
label: BODY

text: County v. Rowley, 458 U.S. 176, 207 (1982).  To that end, the IDEA requires school
label: BODY

text: districts to create an “individualized education program” (IEP) for each disabled child.  Id.  It
label: BODY

text: further authorizes parents challenging their child’s IEP to request an “impartial due process
label: BODY

text: hearing.”  See id. at § 1415(f).  The party that has requested the hearing bears the burden
label: BODY

text: of proof at the hearing.  See Schaffer v. Weast, 126 S.Ct. 528, 537 (2005).
label: BODY

text: A party aggrieved by the findings and decision made in a state administrative due
label: BODY

text: process hearing has the right to bring an original civil action in a state court of competent
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction or in federal district court in order to secure review of the disputed findings and
label: BODY

text: decisions.  See 20 U.S.C. § 1415(i)(2).  The party challenging the decision bears the
label: BODY

text: burden of persuasion on its claim.  See Clyde K. v. Puyallup Sch. Dist. No. 3, 35 F.3d 1396,
label: BODY

text: 1399 (9th Cir. 2004).  In reviewing the administrative decision, the district court “shall
label: BODY

text: receive the records of the administrative proceedings; shall hear additional evidence at the
label: BODY

text: request of a party; and basing its decision on the preponderance of the evidence, shall
label: BODY

text: grant such relief as the court determines is appropriate.”  20 U.S.C. § 1415(i)(2)(B).
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 9 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: This claim is distinguishable from plaintiff’s claim that, because the November
label: BODY

text: 12, 2002 IEP was not based on an Environmental Assessment, the BSP that was developed
label: BODY

text: and which was in operation from July 2003 to November 2003, reflected a denial of a FAPE.
label: BODY

text: Judicial review of state administrative proceedings under the IDEA is less deferential
label: BODY

text: than the review of other agency actions.  See Ojai Unified School District v. Jackson, 4
label: BODY

text: F.3d 1467, 1471 (9th Cir. 1993).  However, “because Congress intended states to have the
label: BODY

text: primary responsibility for formulating each individual child’s education, [courts] must defer
label: BODY

text: to their ‘specialized knowledge and experience’ by giving ‘due weight’ to the decisions of
label: BODY

text: the states’ administrative bodies.”  Amanda J. Ex rel. Annette J. v. Clark County Sch. Dist.,
label: BODY

text: 267 F.3d 877, 888 (9th Cir. 2001).  This review requires the district court to carefully
label: BODY

text: consider the administrative agency’s findings.  See Susan N. v. Wilson Sch. Dist., 70 F.3d
label: BODY

text: 751, 758 (3d. Cir. 1995).  “The amount of deference accorded the hearing officer’s findings
label: BODY

text: increases where they are thorough and careful.”  Capistrano Unified Sch. Dist. v.
label: BODY

text: Wartenberg, 59 F.3d 884, 891 (9th Cir. 1995).  After such consideration, “the court is free to
label: BODY

text: accept or reject the findings in part or in whole.”  Susan N., 70 F.3d at 758.  When the court
label: BODY

text: has before it all the evidence regarding the disputed issues, it may make a final judgment in
label: BODY

text: what “is not a true summary judgment procedure [but] a bench trial based on a stipulated
label: BODY

text: record.”  Ojai, 4 F.3d at 1472.
label: BODY

text: The Parties’ Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment
label: BODY

text: The parties’ cross-motions raise the following issues for resolution: (1) whether the
label: BODY

text: ALJ properly concluded that the District did not deny plaintiff a FAPE from July 19, 2003
label: BODY

text: through the 2005-06 school year; (2) whether the ALJ properly concluded that the District
label: BODY

text: did not deny plaintiff a FAPE from November 13, 2003, through the 2005-06 school year;
label: BODY

text: and (3) whether the ALJ properly conclude that Ms. XXXXXXX was not entitled to reim-
label: BODY

text: bursement for private school placements from March 2004 to June 2006.
label: BODY

text: Preliminarily, however, the court notes that in addition to these issues, plaintiffs raise
label: BODY

text: others that defendant has correctly noted are time-barred.  For example, plaintiffs argue in
label: BODY

text: their papers that the November 2002 IEP that was drafted constituted denial of a FAPE,2
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: United States District Court

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: The ALJ noted July 19, 2006 as the operative date of filing for statute of
label: BODY

text: limitations purposes.
label: BODY

text: A Behavior Intervention Plan is usually developed following a Functional Analysis
label: BODY

text: Assessment (“FAA”) or Functional Behavioral Assessment (“FBA”).  See Cal. Code. Regs. Tit.
label: BODY

text: and that a FAPE was further denied when defendant District failed to include necessary
label: BODY

text: members at the November 12, 2002 and May 1, 2003 IEP meetings.  See Pl. Mot. Summ.
label: BODY

text: Judgm. at 22:24-23:10; 25:24-26:19.  Neither party disputes, however, that plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: claims, which were administratively filed on July 20, 2006, are subject to a three year
label: BODY

text: statute of limitations.  See Cal. Educ. Code § 56505(l), eff. October 7, 2005 to October 8,
label: BODY

text: 2006 (amended by Cal. Educ. Code § 56505(l), eff. October 9, 2006).  Accordingly, plaintiff
label: BODY

text: cannot assert any claims arising out of conduct occurring prior to July 20, 2003, and his
label: BODY

text: claims relating to defendant’s denial of FAPE in connection with the November 12, 2002
label: BODY

text: IEP and IEP meeting, and the May 1, 2003 IEP meeting, are barred.3  Moreover, because
label: BODY

text: the ALJ did not have occasion to pass upon these claims, they are furthermore barred
label: BODY

text: because plaintiff failed to exhaust all administrative remedies in connection with the claims.
label: BODY

text: The court now turns to the substantive issues before it.
label: BODY

text: Whether the District denied plaintiff a FAPE from July 19, 2003 through the
label: BODY

text: 2005-06 school year
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff contends that the District denied him a FAPE for the above-referenced
label: BODY

text: period when it (a) failed to properly assess his behavioral needs; and (b) failed to meet his
label: BODY

text: behavioral needs.  With respect to the former, plaintiff argues that the District failed to
label: BODY

text: conduct an environmental assessment in connection with the November 12, 2002 IEP
label: BODY

text: meeting, leading to an ineffective BSP that failed to meet plaintiff’s needs, and furthermore,
label: BODY

text: that the District failed to offer a Behavior Intervention Plan.4  See Pl. Mot. Summ. Judgment
label: BODY

text: at 21-23.  With respect to the latter, plaintiff argues that the District failed to meet his unique
label: BODY

text: behavioral needs when it failed to refer plaintiff for County Mental Health Services, despite
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 11 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: the fact that plaintiff’s behavior, grades, and attendance record mandated as much.  See id.
label: BODY

text: at 25; see also Pl. Opp. to Summ. Judgm. at 8-10.  For the reasons that follow, however,
label: BODY

text: the court finds that plaintiff’s arguments are without merit.
label: BODY

text: District’s failure to assess plaintiff’s behavioral needs
label: BODY

text: The issue before the court is whether the District failed to conduct an environmental
label: BODY

text: assessment and a FAA or FBA leading to a Behavior Intervention Plan, and if so, whether
label: BODY

text: such failure constituted a denial of a FAPE.  In the underlying administrative decision, the
label: BODY

text: ALJ found that it was unclear whether the District conducted an environmental assessment
label: BODY

text: in November 2002, as witness testimony on the matter was not conclusive.  However, the
label: BODY

text: ALJ found that the team members present at the November 2002 IEP did identify plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: behavior problems and adopted a BSP to deal with those problems, which BSP actually
label: BODY

text: resulted in a decrease in frequency of those behavior problems.  AR 149.  As for whether
label: BODY

text: defendant District was obligated to provide a FAA or FBA, the ALJ found that plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: behavior, as noted in the IEP meeting notes, did not constitute a “serious behavior
label: BODY

text: problem” requiring an FAA, which would have resulted in a Behavior Intervention Plan.
label: BODY

text: While acknowledging that plaintiff’s truancy problem did become a behavior problem in fall
label: BODY

text: of 2003, the ALJ concluded that this was dealt with by defendant District in the November
label: BODY

text: 2003 IEP and BSP.  Id.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff has not pointed to any evidentiary dispute that demonstrates error on the
label: BODY

text: ALJ’s part.  First, even assuming that the District failed to undertake an environmental
label: BODY

text: assessment before the November 2002 BSP was developed and implemented, this failure
label: BODY

text: did not constitute a denial of a FAPE.  Procedural violations – such as the failure to conduct
label: BODY

text: the environmental assessment – only constitute a denial of a FAPE if the violation caused a
label: BODY

text: loss of educational opportunity to the student or significantly infringed on the parents’ right
label: BODY

text: to participate in the IEP process.  See, e.g., R.B., ex rel. F.B.v. Napa Valley Unified School
label: BODY

text: Dist., 496 F.3d 932, 938 (9th Cir. 2007).  Here, the BSP that resulted from the November
label: BODY

text: IEP was intended to address plaintiff’s problems with attendance, punctuality, motivation,
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 12 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: anger, and defiant behaviors.  AR 604-05; 1170; 1249.  And, as the ALJ found, the BSP
label: BODY

text: actually succeeded in decreasing plaintiff’s disruptive behaviors by the beginning of the
label: BODY

text: 2003-04 school year.  AR 652; 977.  Moreover, plaintiff and his mother were present at the
label: BODY

text: November 2002 IEP team meeting at which the BSP was developed.  Plaintiff’s mother did
label: BODY

text: not object, and even consented to the November 2002 IEP and BSP.  AR 306.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, even if the District failed to conduct an environmental assessment in
label: BODY

text: connection with the November 2002 IEP, this did not rise to the level of a denial of a FAPE.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff asserts that his behavior – specifically, plaintiff’s truant behaviors –
label: BODY

text: nonetheless deteriorated following the November 2002 IEP, such that plaintiff’s truancy
label: BODY

text: became the target behavior by the time the November 13, 2003 IEP was prepared and
label: BODY

text: conducted.  Yet the District continued in its failure to conduct proper assessments, resulting
label: BODY

text: in an ineffective November 2003 BSP that failed to properly address plaintiff’s truancy, and
label: BODY

text: therefore also denied plaintiff a FAPE.  While plaintiff contends that his truant behaviors
label: BODY

text: were ignored, the testimony of certain November 2003 IEP team members was that the
label: BODY

text: November 2003 BSP was developed with the express purpose of targeting plaintiff’s truant
label: BODY

text: behaviors, and that this focus had shifted from the prior BSP entered in November 2002.
label: BODY

text: AR 748.  The November 2003 IEP also expressly noted that plaintiff’s “greatest weakness”
label: BODY

text: was truancy, and set forth increased attendance as a goal and objective.  AR 966, 969,
label: BODY

text: 971.  To that end, the revised BSP that was developed at the November 2003 IEP team
label: BODY

text: meeting set forth several proposed adjustments in plaintiff’s educational services in order to
label: BODY

text: address the truancy issues.  Specifically, the revised BSP required daily planner checks,
label: BODY

text: one on one assistance, referral to a truancy probation officer, and phone calls to plaintiff
label: BODY

text: from plaintiff’s teacher and mother when he was not in attendance at school.  AR 748-51;
label: BODY

text: 975.  According to testimony given at the hearing, implementation of this revised BSP did,
label: BODY

text: in fact, help improve plaintiff’s attendance after it was implemented.  AR 752.  Thus, not
label: BODY

text: only was the BSP adopted in November 2003 tailored to meet plaintiff’s unique behavioral
label: BODY

text: needs in the area of truancy – the primary target behavior identified at the time – but the
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 13 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: BSP also resulted in some improvement.  Accordingly, there is no evidence that a failure to
label: BODY

text: properly assess plaintiff’s needs in connection with the November 2003 IEP and
label: BODY

text: subsequent BSP resulted in a loss of educational opportunity for plaintiff, or the denial of a
label: BODY

text: FAPE.
label: BODY

text: Finally, with respect to plaintiff’s contention that the District’s wrongfully failed to
label: BODY

text: conduct an FAA or FBA and to implement a Behavior Intervention Plan, the ALJ properly
label: BODY

text: concluded that no FAA or FBA – and therefore no Behavior Intervention Plan – was
label: BODY

text: necessary.  California law requires that a FAA be undertaken whenever a student develops
label: BODY

text: a “serious behavior problem,” which is defined as a student’s actions exhibiting self-
label: BODY

text: injurious, or assaultive tendencies, or a student’s actions in causing serious property
label: BODY

text: damage or other pervasive and maladaptive tendencies.  See Cal Code Regs., tit. 5 §
label: BODY

text: 3001.  Plaintiff, however, has not pointed to any affirmative evidence in the record that
label: BODY

text: demonstrates, prior to November 2002, either plaintiff’s self-injurious or assaultive
label: BODY

text: tendencies, or plaintiff’s actions causing serious property damage, or defendant District’s
label: BODY

text: knowledge of such.  Accordingly, there is no evidence that supports the existence of a
label: BODY

text: “serious behavior problem” that would have warranted a FAA, FBA, or Behavior
label: BODY

text: Intervention Plan.
label: BODY

text: District’s failure to meet plaintiff’s behavioral needs
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff also asserts that the District denied him a FAPE by refusing to refer him for
label: BODY

text: County Mental Health Services.  The ALJ found that no referral to Mental Health Services
label: BODY

text: was necessary.  AR 149-51.  This was based on the finding that the only significant,
label: BODY

text: frequent behavior preventing plaintiff from benefitting from his education – and possibly
label: BODY

text: triggering a mental health referral – was truancy.  AR 149.  Yet the ALJ found that the
label: BODY

text: District attempted to address the truancy behavior through the November 2003 revised
label: BODY

text: BSP, which in part referred plaintiff to a truancy officer.  AR 150.  This, combined with the
label: BODY

text: testimony of plaintiff’s teachers stating that they did not think plaintiff exhibited a need for
label: BODY

text: mental health services, led the ALJ to conclude that the District’s failure to refer plaintiff did
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 14 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, the ALJ provided sound reasons for discrediting plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: witnesses, who testified that plaintiff needed mental health services while at Hillsdale: those
label: BODY

text: witnesses were not familiar with plaintiff’s placement or services at Hillsdale, and two of them
label: BODY

text: worked with plaintiff more than two years after plaintiff left Hillsdale.  AR 151.  Accordingly,
label: BODY

text: their testimony was speculative.
label: BODY

text: not constitute a denial of FAPE.5  AR 151.
label: BODY

text: In general, the ALJ correctly noted that a local educational agency (“LEA”) such as
label: BODY

text: defendant District may refer a student for community mental health services when the
label: BODY

text: student has emotional or behavioral characteristics that: (1) are observed by qualified
label: BODY

text: educational staff in educational and other settings, as appropriate; (2) impede the pupil
label: BODY

text: from benefitting from educational services; (3) are significant, as indicated by their rate of
label: BODY

text: occurrence and intensity; (4) are associated with a condition that cannot be described
label: BODY

text: solely as a social maladjustment as demonstrated by deliberate noncompliance with
label: BODY

text: accepted social rules, a demonstrated ability to control unacceptable behavior and the
label: BODY

text: absence of a treatable mental disorder; and (5) are associated with a condition that cannot
label: BODY

text: be described solely as a temporary adjustment problem that can be resolved with less than
label: BODY

text: three months of school counseling.  See AR 157; see also Cal. Gov’t Code § 7576 (b)(3).
label: BODY

text: The LEA must also first have provided appropriate services, however, such as counseling
label: BODY

text: or behavioral intervention, and the IEP team must have determined that the services do not
label: BODY

text: meet the student’s individual needs.  See id. at § 7576 (b)(5).
label: BODY

text: Here, plaintiff does not actually identify the emotional or behavioral characteristic
label: BODY

text: that he contends warranted a referral to mental health service.  Plaintiff states only that the
label: BODY

text: District should have made such a referral “based on [plaintiff’s] behavior and the District’s
label: BODY

text: own failed BSPs of November 2002 and November 2003,” and that plaintiff “failed his
label: BODY

text: classes, became a habitual truant and had numerous referrals for discipline.”  See Pl. Opp.
label: BODY

text: to Summ. Judgm. at 9.  Even assuming, however, that truancy, failed classes, and
label: BODY

text: discipline referrals constituted qualifying emotional and/or behavioral characteristics as
label: BODY

text: outlined above, it has not been demonstrated that the District attempted to provide services
label: BODY

text: that were unable to meet plaintiff’s individual needs.  Indeed, as discussed above, the
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 15 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: Defendants point out in their motion for summary judgment that the ALJ’s opinion
label: BODY

text: sometimes states that the November 13, 2003 IEP meeting occurred on November 12, 2003.
label: BODY

text: This appears to be a confusion with the November 12, 2002 IEP meeting.  Accordingly, all
label: BODY

text: references herein are to the November 13, 2003 IEP meeting, notwithstanding the ALJ’s
label: BODY

text: statement to the contrary.
label: BODY

text: evidence demonstrates the opposite – i.e., that the November 2002 and November 2003
label: BODY

text: BSPs actually did succeed in improving the maladaptive behaviors that were noted in
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s respective IEPs.  Furthermore, a Behavior Intervention Plan was not mandated,
label: BODY

text: based on the record presently before the court.
label: BODY

text: In sum, the ALJ’s finding that no referral to County Mental Health Services was
label: BODY

text: required, is supported by the record.  See also AR 150-51; 375-394; 530-32; 553-54; 750-
label: BODY

text: The court therefore affirms the ALJ’s findings and conclusions with respect to the
label: BODY

text: first issue before the court – i.e., whether the District denied plaintiff a FAPE from July 19,
label: BODY

text: 2003 through the 2005-06 school year, by failing to properly assess and/or meet plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: behavioral needs.  Defendant’s motion for summary judgment as to this issue is
label: BODY

text: accordingly GRANTED, and plaintiffs’ cross-motion for summary judgment on the same
label: BODY

text: issue is DENIED.
label: BODY

text: Whether the District denied plaintiff a FAPE from November 13, 2003 through
label: BODY

text: the 2005-06 school year6
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff contends that the District denied him a FAPE for the above-referenced
label: BODY

text: period for several reasons.  Each issue considered by the ALJ, is addressed in turn.
label: BODY

text: failure to have a school psychologist attend the November 13, 2003
label: BODY

text: IEP team meeting
label: BODY

text: The November 2003 IEP meeting consisted of: general education teacher Ms.
label: BODY

text: Rianda, special education teacher Ms. Hahn, speech and language pathologist Ms. Fox,
label: BODY

text: plaintiff, and plaintiff’s mother.  AR 151, 963-975.  Plaintiff, however, contends that the
label: BODY

text: District violated procedure and denied plaintiff a FAPE, because it did not have a school
label: BODY

text: psychologist attend the meeting.
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 16 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: The federal IDEA and the California Education Code require that IEP team meetings
label: BODY

text: include: parents, at least one regular education teacher, at least one special education
label: BODY

text: teacher, a representative of the public agency who is qualified to provide or supervise the
label: BODY

text: provision of instruction designed to meet the needs of children with disabilities, an individual
label: BODY

text: who can interpret the implications of evaluation results, and the child if appropriate.  The
label: BODY

text: last individual may already be a member of the team.  See 34 C.F.R. § 300.344(a)(1999);
label: BODY

text: Cal. Educ. Code § 5634.
label: BODY

text: The ALJ noted that California law provides that where a student is suspected of
label: BODY

text: having a learning disability, at least one member of the team shall be qualified to conduct
label: BODY

text: individual diagnostic examinations of children, such as a school psychologist, speech-
label: BODY

text: language pathologist, or remedial reading teacher.  The Code of Federal Regulations
label: BODY

text: further clarifies that a school psychologist’s attendance is required only when determining
label: BODY

text: eligibility under the learning disability category.  Accordingly, since plaintiff here had already
label: BODY

text: had his eligibility under the law determined, the ALJ concluded that no school psychologist
label: BODY

text: was required to attend the November 2002 IEP meeting.  Furthermore, the ALJ noted that
label: BODY

text: in addition to the attendance of speech and language pathologist Ms. Fox at the November
label: BODY

text: 2002 IEP meeting, Ms. Rianda and Ms. Hahn both gave testimony at the hearing that their
label: BODY

text: education and training included training in drafting BSPs.  Accordingly, the ALJ concluded
label: BODY

text: that while helpful, a school psychologist was not required by either state or federal law.
label: BODY

text: Not only are the ALJ’s observations with respect to the law thorough and accurate,
label: BODY

text: but plaintiff has not introduced any law or evidence here that contradicts these conclusions.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the court concludes that the ALJ was correct in deciding that the District did
label: BODY

text: not deny plaintiff a FAPE by not having a school psychologist attend the November 2003
label: BODY

text: IEP meeting.
label: BODY

text: failure to assess plaintiff in the areas of behavior, speech and
label: BODY

text: language, and academics
label: BODY

text: The ALJ concluded that the District did not deny plaintiff a FAPE by failing to assess
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 17 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff does contend that the District failed to offer plaintiff direct speech
label: BODY

text: language therapy when it switched to consultation services as part of the November 2003 IEP.
label: BODY

text: However, this is more properly construed as an argument that defendant failed to provide
label: BODY

text: proper services, rather than an argument relating to defendant’s failure to assess plaintiff, and
label: BODY

text: is addressed below, in connection with defendant’s purported failure to meet plaintiff’s unique
label: BODY

text: speech and language needs.
label: BODY

text: plaintiff in the areas of behavior, speech and language, and academics.  With respect to
label: BODY

text: behavior, and as mentioned above, the ALJ concluded that the District assessed plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: behavioral needs when it modified plaintiff’s BSP in November 2003.  With respect to
label: BODY

text: speech and language, as well as academics, the ALJ concluded that the District was
label: BODY

text: required by law to assess plaintiff in all areas related to his disability at least once every
label: BODY

text: three years, unless the parent and the school agree in writing that a reassessment is
label: BODY

text: unnecessary.  AR 152.  And since the District conducted its triennial assessment of plaintiff
label: BODY

text: in fall 2002 with three diagnostic tests – the WRAT, Bruckner math test, and the PIAT –
label: BODY

text: there was no need to reassess plaintiff between fall of 2002 and March of 2004, when
label: BODY

text: plaintiff left Hillsdale.  AR 152, 587.  Furthermore, the ALJ noted that plaintiff had
label: BODY

text: introduced no evidence warranting reassessment in November 2003, nor did the record
label: BODY

text: reflect that plaintiff’s mother had requested reassessment.  AR 152.
label: BODY

text: As is repeatedly the case in the motion papers, plaintiff has failed to present any
label: BODY

text: evidence that presents a dispute of fact on the relevant issues.  Plaintiff mentions almost no
label: BODY

text: evidence7 relating to the District’s purported failure to assess plaintiff academically, and as
label: BODY

text: for the District’s speech and language assessment, plaintiff also fails to point to any
label: BODY

text: evidence that would indicate a failure to assess plaintiff as required by law.  Moreover,
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s mother never requested reassessment as to the District’s speech and language
label: BODY

text: assessments.  AR 316.
label: BODY

text: In sum, there is no dispute present that calls into question the ALJ’s conclusion that
label: BODY

text: the district properly assessed plaintiff’s behavioral, academic, and speech and language
label: BODY

text: needs from July 19, 2003 through the 2005-06 school year.
label: BODY

text: failure to provide adequate present levels of performance in the
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 18 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: November 13, 2003 IEP in the areas of behavior, speech and
label: BODY

text: language, and academics
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff also asserts that the District failed to provide adequate present levels of
label: BODY

text: performance in the November 2003 IEP in the areas of behavior, speech and language,
label: BODY

text: and academics.  As defendants acknowledge, the IDEA requires that a student’s annual
label: BODY

text: IEP contain a statement of the student’s present levels of academic achievement and
label: BODY

text: performance, including the manner in which the student’s disability affects his or her
label: BODY

text: involvement and progress in the general education curriculum.  See 20 U.S.C. §
label: BODY

text: The ALJ noted that the November 2003 IEP contained limited information about
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s present levels of performance.  While it listed some information, such as plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: strengths and preferences, his scores on some testing, and his areas of need, the IEP did
label: BODY

text: not contain specific information regarding academic assessments, or regarding the goals
label: BODY

text: and objectives for plaintiff.  AR 152.  This was because of plaintiff’s excessive truancy.  The
label: BODY

text: IEP states: “current testing has not been performed due to excessive absences...”.  Id.; see
label: BODY

text: also AR 969.  Nor did the November 2003 IEP contain any “baseline” data from which
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s student performance may be assessed.  AR 152.  The ALJ found, however, that
label: BODY

text: because plaintiff’s teachers and speech therapist established that they were familiar with
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s needs from working with him in the past and seeing him occasionally in fall 2003,
label: BODY

text: they were able to make knowledgeable recommendations about plaintiff’s IEP program.  Id.
label: BODY

text: Now, plaintiff contends that the ALJ’s conclusion was error, because the District’s
label: BODY

text: failure to assess his present academic levels made it (a) impossible to determine if the
label: BODY

text: goals proposed adequately addressed plaintiff’s academic needs, and (b) made it
label: BODY

text: impossible for Ms. XXXXXXX to determine if the District’s offered program met plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: needs.
label: BODY

text: These arguments fail to persuade.  As to the former, while true that the November
label: BODY

text: 2003 IEP expressly stated that current testing could not be performed due to “excessive
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 19 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: absences,” the IEP does contain descriptions of plaintiff’s performance to the extent
label: BODY

text: possible, including notations regarding plaintiff’s attendance problems, failure to turn in
label: BODY

text: paperwork, GPA score, and the credits required to graduate.  AR 1274.  The IEP also
label: BODY

text: states that until plaintiff “attends school regularly, the current placement will continue to be
label: BODY

text: the least restrictive and most appropriate environment for [plaintiff.]”  Id.  Moreover, the IEP
label: BODY

text: that was left in place was designed, as the ALJ found, by teachers with knowledge of
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s needs and past performance, and the BSP that was newly revised at the
label: BODY

text: November 2003 IEP meeting was specifically done with the purpose of aiding the truancy
label: BODY

text: problems so that plaintiff could get back on track academically.  Therefore, even though the
label: BODY

text: District was admittedly unable to assess plaintiff’s present levels of performance
label: BODY

text: thoroughly, the District was still able to make knowledgeable recommendations regarding
label: BODY

text: plaintiff’s proposed IEP, and to recommend a BSP that would target plaintiff’s truancy and
label: BODY

text: allow him to benefit from his education.
label: BODY

text: As for plaintiff’s argument that the lack of present levels of performance made it
label: BODY

text: impossible for Ms. XXXXXXX to participate and determine whether the District’s
label: BODY

text: educational offerings met plaintiff’s needs, plaintiff does not dispute that Ms. XXXXXXX was
label: BODY

text: present at the November 2003 IEP team meeting, or that Ms. XXXXXXX subsequently
label: BODY

text: consented to the November 2003 IEP without raising any objections, either at the meeting
label: BODY

text: or afterwards.  AR 315-16.  Nor does plaintiff submit any legal authority that suggests that a
label: BODY

text: parent’s lack of meaningful participation in the IEP process occurs under factual
label: BODY

text: circumstances similar to the case at bar.
label: BODY

text: In sum, to the extent that the District failed to include present levels of performance
label: BODY

text: in connection with the November 13, 2003 IEP, it did not constitute a denial of a FAPE.
label: BODY

text: failure to include adequate goals in the November 13, 2003 IEP in the
label: BODY

text: areas of behavior, speech and language, academics, and mental
label: BODY

text: health
label: BODY

text: This issue is related to the preceding issue.  Plaintiff contends that, since the District
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 20 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: failed to ascertain plaintiff’s present levels of performance in connection with the November
label: BODY

text: 2003 IEP, then the District also failed to provide adequate goals, as required by IDEA.  See
label: BODY

text: 20 U.S.C. § 1414(d)(1)(A)(i)(II); Cal. Educ. Code § 56345(a)(2).  For the following reasons,
label: BODY

text: plaintiff is incorrect.
label: BODY

text: First, as discussed above, the District’s failure to include present levels of
label: BODY

text: performance did not constitute a denial of FAPE.  Accordingly, plaintiff’s argument that the
label: BODY

text: same led to a failure to provide adequate goals, fails.  Second, the evidence demonstrates
label: BODY

text: that the November 2003 IEP did include goals that were adequately tailored to plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: needs.  Specifically, the IEP included a statement of goals related to academic
label: BODY

text: performance (through improved attendance), literacy skills (through the writing of
label: BODY

text: expository essays), in math skills (through completion of math homework), and mental
label: BODY

text: health skills (BSP stated goal of “cooperative and positive attendance”).  AR 966-67; 976.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff, moreover, does not dispute that these goals were included.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the ALJ’s conclusion that the District’s purported failure to include
label: BODY

text: adequate goals in the November 13, 2003 IEP in the areas of behavior, speech and
label: BODY

text: language, academics, and mental health did not constitute a denial of a FAPE, is well-
label: BODY

text: founded.  The court hereby affirms the ALJ’s decision in this regard.
label: BODY

text: failure to meet plaintiff’s unique speech and language needs in the
label: BODY

text: areas of dysfluency, and expressive receptive and pragmatic language
label: BODY

text: skills
label: BODY

text: Finally, plaintiff contends that the District denied him a FAPE when it failed to meet
label: BODY

text: his unique speech and language needs, and expressive receptive and pragmatic language
label: BODY

text: skills.  Specifically, plaintiff asserts that the District failed to do so when it adjusted plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: direct speech therapy to a consultation based service as part of the November 2003 IEP.
label: BODY

text: Plaintiff was receiving direct speech language therapy until the November 2003 IEP.
label: BODY

text: At the November 2003 IEP, plaintiff’s teachers determined that the best therapy would be
label: BODY

text: via consultation services.  This was in part because of plaintiff’s truancy.  As plaintiff’s
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 21 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: speech and language therapist testified, although she was reluctant to switch plaintiff to
label: BODY

text: consultation services, she felt that “there was a power struggle that was going to get set up
label: BODY

text: around speech.”  AR 690-91.  She wanted speech “to be the place [plaintiff] comes to ... to
label: BODY

text: work on goals.” AR 691.  Furthermore, plaintiff was missing so many classes that he was
label: BODY

text: failing, and it would be “counterproductive” from “an educational point of view,” to have
label: BODY

text: plaintiff show up on the rare occasion, only to have to pull him out of general education
label: BODY

text: classes for speech therapy.  To that end, the recommendation was made to switch plaintiff
label: BODY

text: to consultation services, to “hopefully give the behavior plan a chance to work, get him
label: BODY

text: back into school more regularly so that [the speech-language therapist] could re-engage
label: BODY

text: with him in a productive way.”  AR 690.  Otherwise, plaintiff’s therapist continued, “it was a
label: BODY

text: totally unproductive, unworkable therapeutic plan.”  Id.
label: BODY

text: The ALJ found that plaintiff’s speech and language therapist, who testified to the
label: BODY

text: above, was a “credible and persuasive witness,” and that her testimony established the fact
label: BODY

text: that direct speech therapy “no longer facilitated [plaintiff’s] overall educational needs.” AR
label: BODY

text: 153.  Furthermore, because plaintiff had already benefitted from years of speech therapy,
label: BODY

text: the pause in direct therapy sessions would only minimally impact plaintiff’s ability to
label: BODY

text: improve his speech fluency.  Finally, the ALJ found that plaintiff had presented no contrary
label: BODY

text: evidence on the issue.
label: BODY

text: Here, plaintiff argues only that the District’s decision to switch to consultation
label: BODY

text: services was akin to “giving up” on its student – precisely what Congress sought to prevent
label: BODY

text: when it enacted the IDEA.  However, plaintiff offers no authority or contrary evidence in
label: BODY

text: support of this argument.  Indeed, the only evidence in the record – Ms. Fox’s testimony –
label: BODY

text: established that the District was not giving up on plaintiff, and that it was attempting
label: BODY

text: everything possible to ensure plaintiff’s continued improvement.  In sum, plaintiff has not
label: BODY

text: presented evidence that warrants reversal of the ALJ’s holding on this issue.
label: BODY

text: In conclusion, and with respect to the second issue presented before the ALJ – i.e.,
label: BODY

text: whether the District denied plaintiff a FAPE from November 13, 2003 through the 2005-06
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 22 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: school year – the ALJ’s decision is affirmed, and summary judgment is GRANTED in
label: BODY

text: defendant’s favor, and DENIED as to plaintiffs.
label: BODY

text: Whether Ms. XXXXXXX was entitled to reimbursement for private school
label: BODY

text: placements from March 2004 to June 2006
label: BODY

text: Having concluded that the ALJ’s decision is to be affirmed, the court also concludes
label: BODY

text: that Ms. XXXXXXX was not entitled to reimbursement for private school placements from
label: BODY

text: March 2004 to June 2006.  For without proof that plaintiff was denied a FAPE, no
label: BODY

text: reimbursement for such denial is appropriate.  See Burlington v. Dep’t of Educ., 471 U.S.
label: BODY

text: 359, 374 (1985)(“If the courts ultimately determine that the IEP proposed by the school
label: BODY

text: officials was appropriate, the parents would be barred from obtaining reimbursement for
label: BODY

text: any interim period in which their child’s placement violated § 1415(e)(3)”).
label: BODY

text: Moreover, as the ALJ noted, for the entire length of plaintiff’s attendance at private
label: BODY

text: schools, Ms. XXXXXXX failed to notify the District of any intent to seek reimbursement.  AR
label: BODY

text: 154.  The IDEA provides that reimbursement may be denied or reduced if the parents do
label: BODY

text: not give the school district notice of their intent to remove a child from public school before
label: BODY

text: they do so.  See, e.g., 20 U.S.C. § 1412(a)(10)(C)(iii)(I).  Generally, parents must provide
label: BODY

text: such notice at the most recent IEP meeting that the parents attended prior to the removal of
label: BODY

text: the child from the public school, or by written notice ten business days prior to the removal
label: BODY

text: of the child from public school.  Id.
label: BODY

text: Here, plaintiff was arrested in May 2003.  AR 995.  Several months later, the
label: BODY

text: November 2003 IEP meeting took place.  Around that time (in November or December
label: BODY

text: 2003), plaintiff’s private therapist first recommended that plaintiff attend the Rocky
label: BODY

text: Mountain Academy as an alternative to Hillsdale.  AR 345-46.  Yet there is no evidence that
label: BODY

text: plaintiff or his mother informed the District of either plaintiff’s arrest or the private therapist’s
label: BODY

text: recommended education placement, at the November 2003 IEP team meeting, or
label: BODY

text: thereafter.  Subsequent to 2003, plaintiff appeared in court in January 2004, at which
label: BODY

text: appearance the court stated that plaintiff could go to Rocky Mountain Academy, which is
label: BODY

text: Case 3:07-cv-02360-PJH     Document 36      Filed 07/03/2008     Page 23 of 24
label: BODY

text: United States District Court
label: HH2

text: For the Northern District of California
label: BODY

text: part of the CEDU program.  AR 323.  Two months later, in March 2004, plaintiff was
label: BODY

text: adjudged a ward of the court.  AR 996.  Still, throughout all this time, there is no evidence
label: BODY

text: that plaintiff or his mother informed the District of the potential private placement.  In fact,
label: BODY

text: Ms. XXXXXXX did not contact the District to inform them of plaintiff’s private placement until
label: BODY

text: March 22, 2004, after plaintiff had been adjudged a ward of the court and after plaintiff had
label: BODY

text: already left for private placement at Ascent [plaintiff went to Ascent instead of Rocky
label: BODY

text: Mountain Academy].  AR 837, 998, 1002.  Even then, Ms. XXXXXXX never requested
label: BODY

text: reimbursement from the District.  The first time the District learned of the request for
label: BODY

text: reimbursement was when she filed the due process complaint in the underlying
label: BODY

text: administrative action.
label: BODY

text: On balance, these facts demonstrate a complete failure to provide adequate notice
label: BODY

text: to the District of plaintiff’s private placement.  Accordingly, even if a denial of a FAPE had
label: BODY

text: been demonstrated, no reimbursement would be appropriate.  For all the foregoing
label: BODY

text: reasons, therefore, the court also affirms the ALJ’s decision that reimbursement is not
label: BODY

text: warranted.  Defendant’s motion for summary judgment on this ground is GRANTED.  The
label: BODY

text: court DENIES plaintiffs’ cross-motion with respect to the reimbursement issue.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion
label: BODY

text: The ALJ’s decision is thorough, organized, and detailed, warranting a higher level of
label: BODY

text: deference.  To that end, the decision is affirmed in all respects.  Defendant’s motion for
label: BODY

text: summary judgment is GRANTED, and plaintiffs’ cross-motion for summary judgment is
label: BODY

text: DENIED.
label: BODY

text: IT IS SO ORDERED.
